title: World number three Mark Williams ‘quite close’ to walking away from snooker
text:
Mark Williams is considering his future in the game (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

Mark Williams has admitted that this could be his last season in snooker as he struggles to find enjoyment and motivation for the game.

The world number three reached the final of the China Championship last month and made it to the semi-finals of the Six-red World Championship two weeks earlier.

The three-time world champion won through to the second round of the English Open on Tuesday, beating Jamie Clarke 4-2, but after the victory, admitted that he is really struggling to motivate himself and could be nearing the end of his career.

‘I’ve got plenty of time to practice, I’m just not, I don’t want to go to the club,’ Williams told Eurosport. ‘In 12 months I’ve probably been in there 10 times.

‘I just find a reason not to go in and practice; cinema, golf, whatever. I’m enjoying not playing which is strange for me because I’m not like that.

‘This is the longest I’ve ever felt like this, sometimes a couple of months or whatever before, but there’s no sign of me snapping out of this one.

Williams is number three in the world rankings (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

‘When I lose it doesn’t really hurt that much, but I never have through my career, to be honest, at the end of the day it’s just a snooker match.

‘You only get out what you put in in this game and I’ve been putting nothing in and getting nothing out, which is what I deserve.’

The 44-year-old was asked how close he has come to bringing his career to an end, to which he replied: ‘I’m quite close to be honest, I’ll see what happens at the end of the Worlds and re-evaluate.

‘I’ll see [about retirement at the end of the season], I wouldn’t have thought so, but I’ll see. I’m not saying I’m going to, but it’s something I’ll think about.’

Williams won his third world title just last year and has lifted the World Open trophy since then, but he says he just cannot rediscover his love for the game.

‘I’m number three in the world still, but I’m not enjoying it,’ said the Welsh legend.

‘I’m still trying 100% when I’m out there, I’ll play hour frames, I don’t mind, but I’m not putting the work in and I don’t want to.’

Williams returns to action in the second round of the English Open on Wednesday against Michael Holt.
